awd_titl_txt: Belmont Forum Collaborative Research Food-Water-Energy Nexus: Food-Energy-Water for Sustainable Urban Environments
awd_abstract_narration:
Many cities across the globe are facing difficult challenges managing their food, water and energy systems. The challenges stem from the fact that the issues of food, water and energy are often tightly connected with each other, not only locally but also globally. This is known as the Food-Water-Energy (FWE) nexus.  An effective solution to a local water problem may cause new local problems with food or energy, or cause new water problems at the global level. On a local scale, it is difficult to anticipate whether solutions to one issue in the nexus are sustainable across food, water and energy systems, both at the local and the global scale.  Innovative solutions that encompass the nexus are particularly important to enable cities to better manage their food, water and energy systems and understand the benefits and tradeoffs for different solutions.  

This award supports U.S. researchers participating in a project competitively selected by a 29-country initiative through the joint Belmont Forum- Joint Programming Initiative (JPI) Urban Europe.  The Sustainable Urbanization Global Initiative (SUGI)/Food-Water-Energy Nexus is a multilateral initiative designed to support research projects that bring together the fragmented research and expertise across the globe to find innovative solutions to the Food-Water-Energy Nexus challenge.  The call seeks to develop more resilient, applied urban solutions to benefit a much wider range of stakeholders. The rapid urbanization of the world's population underscores the importance of this focus. International partners were invited to develop solutions for this challenge.  The funds requested will be used to support U.S. participants to cooperate in consortia that consist of partners from at least three of the participating countries and that bring together natural scientists, social scientists and research users (e.g., civil society, NGOs, and industry).  Participants from other countries are funded through their national funding organizations. 

The project adopts a systems approach to understand urban food-water-energy systems and quantify the impacts of proposed solutions for monsoonal (Pune, India) and semi-arid regions (Amman, Jordan).  Models for each region will be developed to capture connections and feedbacks among users, producers, distribution mechanisms, and resources.  Together with a wide range of actors in these cities, the project will develop narratives of future changes in environment, demographics, land use, and economic development, under which the models will be used to develop and evaluate implementable sustainability options.  Sustainability Living Labs will aid stakeholders to identify means to overcome impediments to sustainability and resource equity. The project framework is flexible, transferrable, and broadly applicable to the urban-food-water-energy challenges and it is anticipated that this platform will be useful to many geographic regions where adequate models of the food-water-energy system can be developed.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
FUSE was a multi-year project consisting of an interdisciplinary, international team aimed at developing long-term water-food-energy systems models. Applied to the Amman, Jordan and Pune, India regions, we develop integrated models to capture connections and feedbacks among users, producers, distribution mechanisms, and resources connecting the food-water-energy nexus. Under narratives of future changes in climate, demographics, land use, and economic development, and considering the behavior of a wide range of actors, we developed and evaluated policy interventions to identify implementable sustainability options.

Our analysis relied on a combination of remote sensing for land-cover change determination, hydrologic simulation, water-agricultural-energy supply and demand estimation, crop yield quantification, and economic and historical systems analyses. We engaged in stakeholder participatory model building to construct user-inspired and user-oriented future narratives and potential solutions. We then presented the research results as the basis for Living Lab workshop discussions with stakeholders about the benefits and deficiencies of those solutions and identification of means to overcome impediments to sustainability and resource equity. 

FUSE implemented a three-step procedure. First, in 2019 we conducted co-creation Living Labs to obtain stakeholder and expert expressions of their current challenges involving the provision of food-water-energy. These groups then provided their vision of how to achieve greater sustainability in the face of future scenarios involving rapid population growth, land-use change, and climate change. Stakeholders from various NGOs and other local and regional organizations identified their current and future challenges, and then experts identified potential solutions involving various economic, social, regulatory, and infrastructural reforms. Second, we constructed policy-evaluation models to explore the future options provided by the experts to determine to what degree these reforms might be effective. The models represent the relevant biophysics, such as hydrology and agricultural production, as well as the spectrum of agents that represent human decision-making and response. We identified a series of metrics by which future well-being outcomes were compared. These metrics measured how vulnerability affects  different resource-users in different socio-economic categories. The integrated multi-agent model was tested against historical data and then simulations run into the future to explore the potential outcomes of the various proposed individual and combined solutions. Third, the model results were presented to the same groups, or nearly the same groups, of stakeholders and experts during 2021 and 2022 workshops. Their reactions and preferences were recorded, as well as their assessment of the integrated model and its utility for future planning.

In Jordan, we completed and presented the coupled human-natural system Jordan Water Model and the results of our analysis of water sustainability policy. We showed that with droughts becoming more frequent, longer, and severe coupled with population growth, that water scarcity would become much worse in the coming decades. We evaluated supply-side and demand-side interventions, and we showed that only a portfolio of extraordinary measures would result in sufficient and equitable water provision. In 2023, we extended the model to focus on the illegal tanker truck water market, which we determined was about ten times the size of the government sanctioned market, depriving the state of revenue that could be used to improve the nation's water infrastructure for water provision.

In 2022 in India, we presented initial development of our integrated model involving evaluation of policy options for their food-water-energy system with a focus on the city of Pune. The model was informed by analysis of nearly 2000 household surveys in Pune, the development of a comprehensive hydrologic simulation model and agricultural economic model for the Bhima basin containing Pune, and analysis of stakeholder challenges. In two sets of final workshops in Pune, the model results were well-received, and constructive comments were provided and documented. Results showed that during a future drought period under climate change, populations growth, and urbanization, the city and region will be in dire straits. The surface water reservoirs will empty during a third drought year, groundwater will become depleted, agricultural production diminished, and a large number of poor urban residents would have access to a minimal quantity of water. Various policy interventions included transfers from other reservoirs to Pune, and expanding the tanker truck market to access groundwater outside of the Pune metropolitan area. Although these interventions showed some benefit for a two-year future drought, none of these interventions were successful in mitigating the impacts of an extended drought in its third year. 

During this project we published 23 journal papers, including ones in PNAS and Nature Sustainability and two a series of workshop reports. We published three policy blogs at the Brookings Institution Planet Policy, Wilson Center New Security Beat, and the University of Virginia Global Water Blog, respectively. In addition, we co-produced three professional short videos describing activities of the FUSE project. Our work has already been well received with  our publications downloaded and cited.
